description:
How does media enable religious practitioners to experience the divine in
the immediacy of the “here and now”? Prayer, liturgy, chanting,
meditation, and acts of remembering to commune with higher powers, are
acts that incorporate audio-visual technologies, t.v., radio, internet,
religious texts, art, relics, icons, as well as so-called “idols” and “fetishes.”
Focusing on the intersection of religion and media, students will analyze
“sensational forms,” and religious conceptions of how to properly
represent the divine (“semiotic theologies”). By examining media use of
several religious communities around the world, the course highlights
critical aspects of religious practice and religious difference.
title: Religion and the Media Turn
prerequisite:
Recommended, not required: YSS2227 Introduction to Anthropology,
YSS2209 Anthropological Imagination, or YSS3202 Ethnography
